title: Ramps 1.4 Enclosure for Vslot, a bit bigger
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The original is great, but I wanted more room for playing and better accessibility for changes.
The original is 120x80mm and 60mm high.
Much of it is just an imitation of the original box by spauda01, why spoil a good thing. ;-)
For accessibility I introduced some cable slots with different sized slides.

Update (9-13-17):
I replaced the boxes with cable slots with much leaner ones: 37% less filament needed.
New measurements: 130x115x99mm and 130x115x77mm.
They are as sturdy as before around the cable slots and the main structure is about the same, but the bottom and walls are thinner at many places. Min. thickness 1.6mm (I use a nozzle of 0.4mm). Also: 2 mounting points are enough.
As before, the 99mm version is intended for when one wants to add a CNC shield (mount) or whatever.
I made some room for wires etc. under the Ramps and the reset button is now easier to use via the "reset-button.stl".
Theoretically one could cut a M3-thread in 3 of the print supports, not easy to reach though, but the support with the point sticking out made that unnecessary. When you would want to do it, use nylon bolts.

I was too lazy to change the version with fixed cable holes (150x112x70mm). I don't use it myself, but if anybody would like a leaner version of that, please tell and I'll see what I can do with it.

The CNC-shield in the picture is not connected, don't use it at the moment, it's just there for the show. The colored blocks in some of the pictures represent the max. room the p.c.'s need with the connected wires plus the fan. After printing I made the rear ventilation holes a bit higher and thinner (a bit more flesh between the holes). It prints nice with "touching bed" support in curaengine, easy to remove.

I removed most of the history from this text. I think this is the ultimate version (for me, at least ;-) ), keep it open for a little while as a work in progress, dependent of eventual welcome comments.

Edit (10/21/17) Tinkered a bit with the ramp-supports -> Ramps-box...-v1.stl

Printer:

D-Bot Core_XY in Threes

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

"Touching Bed Support" in curaengine in Repetier Host.

comments.text: Any chance of adding Rasperry Pi mounting in the larger one?
comments.author: RigoArevalo

comments.text: I am very busy now, but I'll keep it in the back of my mind. So, can't give you any promises or prospects, but will do as soon as... ;-)
comments.author: RigoArevalo

comments.text:
Had a quick look at the Raspberry Pi in connection to this box and saw that is was more complicated then I thought, with all those connections, the extra room and weight and such.
Not so easy as with the CNC shield. And however I would do that, if I could, the result would be an unapproachable RPi, I'm afraid.
So, no, I am not going to try. Sorry.

comments.text: Try to orient it with the flat "non-clip" surface down towards your build plate. That is the way I have all the STL files setup, for some reason once uploaded to thingiverse they change the orientation. You should only need a small support for the internal overhang of the clip.
comments.author: Hinrg

comments.text: Thank you for these, i should have searched harder to find your 1.75" kit before making my last comment.  Just wondering if ABS is the only material that works well for these pieces, or will other types of material still click together just as well?  Also is there another cheaper printer you could recommend?  Appreciated. Lee
comments.author: Funkyflynz

comments.text: The snap parts that I have personally printed I have used ABS, and have had good luck with them. I haven't broken a snap tab or had any part failures yet. With that said, the part durability will change depending on the brand of filament and the filament type. I know that the ABS used in my zortrax printer is a slightly different composition then other makes ABS filament. I left a decent enough tolerance between the snap tabs and the corresponding base, so it should apply minimal stress to the tab while still holding strong. With that said, I would suggest you print with at least a 60-75% infill for optimal strength. But this is all subjective to your machine, and what settings you have tested with in the past.
comments.author: Funkyflynz

title: Easy print D12, 20mm high, beveled digits

description.text: I tried http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33313 and found the digits too sharp and caused print issues. I have made this one with the digits impressed with beveled edges, and it seems to work. Also made 20mm high. Works well sprayed with acrylic paint to fill the digits. I also made the digits all the same way up in the pentagons (i.e with point at top and flat at bottom). Whilst this would allow 6 and 9 to work without an underline, I decided it would avoid arguments to leave that in. I could not find a definitive reference for ordering of the digits, so I did it so facing 1, you see clockwise 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and of course the opposites that add to 13 (which does seem to be standard). The other problem was that one side was flat on base and one was last layer, so did not look the same - this is solved by printing it all on an edge or a corner. To my surprise this works even with a sharp edged dodecahedron like this.

Just prints on a makerbot, no support. To give some weight I did 90% fill.  
I have included a version on its edge - to my surprise this prints, even though held in place by one line of filiment as it is a sharp edge. However, the result is that no face was flat top or bottom and they all look the same and much better as a result.  
I have also added one printing on the coner - this gives best angles for underside to print cleanly and look good. For this it has a cross hairs support which is easy to remove.

description.text:
This is my version of the Dyson Exhaust Duct (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:868329) by jgschmidt.
I took his design, made the walls 1mm thicker (now 3mm), and incorporated two expansion sections in the locating collar.
The expansion sections were included after I made Jürgen's design, tried to fit it to my DC44, and the raised fins on the motor exhaust split the locating collar.

This was redrawn from scratch on Fusion 360

Just be careful fitting it - IT IS STILL REALLY EASY TO SPLIT IT!!

For best result of printing the Box for you must:

2- Calculate in your slicer just part (Prints.stl).
3- Print calculated (Prints.stl) file in white color.
4- Remove from your print plate frame and leave on it just printed letters/simbols.
5- Calculate in your slicer part (Top Box.stl).
6- Print calculated part (Top Box.stl) in Black color (Without suports!!!).
7- Remove printed Top Box part from plate.
8- Calculate and print (Bottom Box) part in black color.
9- Calculate and print (Button) part in yellow color.
10- Assemble printed parts with 3m screws

title: Space-filling molecular models: Phenanthrene adventure pack

description.text:
What better way so show your love for your favorite chemist than with a space-filling molecular model of a molecule that just happens to look like a lacy valentine! Just think, if you were to give your true love a single gram of phenanthrene, they would have 3.4 x 10^21 valentines (albeit very small and difficult to personalize). Phenanthrene is easily available from most chemical supply houses (CAS 85-01-8), but it doesn't smell particularly nice, so you're probably better off just giving your sweetheart the model. Some folks may notice that I've chosen a non-traditional color for carbon; there's no rule that says that carbon has to be black.

You'll need

10 CarbonPH6 in your choice of color
2 CarbonJPH1 in the same color
10 Hydrogen in a different color
24 bonds in any color

I've included some files grouping these objects if it helps.

Assembly tips:

The bonds are tight, so I have included a tool to help insert them. Join one CarbonPH6 to each CarbonJPH1 using the rectangular holes (the round ones go out). Snap these two assemblies together. Then join a hydrogen to each of two CarbonPH1's by the round holes and snap them to the top of the other assembly (there won't be enough room to add these hydrogens later). The hydrogens may be too close together, so you will probably have to sand them a little. Then make two groups of three CarbonPH6's using the rectangular holes and snap these to the sides of the other assembly. Add the remaining hydrogens to the remaining (hopefully round) holes and you're done.

If you now have an uncontrollable desire to make more molecules, you should probably critically evaluate your love life, however the following files are provided for the hopeless: the starter set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1720048), the carbon expansion set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1730299), the aromatic expansion set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1754393), halogen expansion set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1730099), nitrogen expansion set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1753583), and sulfur and phosphorus expansion pack (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2350618)

Printer:

Da Vinci 1A

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10%, 30% for bond tool

Notes:

I used ABS. Three perimeters works well.

title: Omnibus F3 AIO V1.1 Flight Controller Case

description.text:
This is a simple case to allow this neat little flight controller to be installed in a fixed wing, or protected on a larger multirotor. The Barometer is on the top of the board so a piece of foam needs to placed over it and secured using the top half of the enclosure.

23Jan17 - UPDATE: Top cover had been tweaked a little to provide a more flush fit and strength. It also includes a small raised peg to help keep any baro protecting foam in place! Also, new bottom plate includes extra cooling for the DC-DC converter mounted on the bottom of the board.

You can see is using the board (and enclosure) in the future videos of our iNavflight series on YouTube - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ha9haq_eIcs

Happy printing and flying!

description.text: This was an HO size container that I enlarged for Lionel doublestack intermodal cars. I have been told that they are actually S Scale and not true 1:48 Don't know don't care. They fit the Lionel cars. I added the US Army Chemical Corps logo on the side as they are close to a 1 ton container.
a turnable caster wheel in scale 1:12

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Finder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

high

Infill:

10-15%

Notes:

I used simplify 3d printing this wheel, with no raft and no supports. Works great if you print everything flat...the wheel, wheelplate and wheelsocket.
Scale 1:12 and i used 1mm metalthread (jewelry pins) as axel for the wheel.

yet another headphone wall mount

Small set of copy-paste flap elements that can be used in your engineering project.

I've been asked many times by my customers about snap-fit parts design requirements. This entry is especially for them wanting to be sure their designs are easy printable and functional. This setup is tested several times on Zortrax M200.

Just download and boolean with existing design or treat as the starting point.
Need more control over shape? Use Fusion 360 CAD original parts:

Latch: http://a360.co/2j8dEls
Snap-lock: http://a360.co/2iXCaTa
Hinge: http://a360.co/2kdWk0l
Slide: http://a360.co/2j8a0bp

Hope to see many great projects involving this!

title: Customizable pet ladder, ideal for birds, hamsters etc.

description.text:
I designed this for my African Grey but would suit many pets. Should be customised to suit your particular pet/cage.

You can easily change the overall width and height as well as the thickness of the rungs and the spacing between them. Just click the customizer link above it is really simple!

Features rounded edges to reduce the chance of injury and make it harder for your pet to nibble on!

Please ensure your pet doesn't eat this as the plastic may be harmful. I recommend printing in PLA since it should have a lower toxicity than many other plastics though still doesn't mitigate all risk.

I needed a gimbal holder/bracket. And this one slides on one of the lips on your Q450
you need to configure the quad so you can put this on the front or back.
I used the HK gimbal with cheap servos, then cut off the mounting plate.
I needed 100 mm clearance under the quad. It goes great together with the legs i made(see my other things).
Printed on printrbot with 0.3 mm layers and 0.5 straight fill.

description.text:
Boom...Boom...RooAArrRR!!! A T-Rex Footprint Cookie Cutter approaches! You wouldn't believe how hard I tried to get a sweet photo of a ripple of water in a glass next to this cookie cutter. I ended up pounding my fist on the kitchen table one too many times attempting to get that classic Jurassic Park cup ripple next to this cookie cutter. Anyway you'll just have to do without it. Feel free to print at different scales, everything should work fine. Make a bunch of cookies and post pictures! Maybe even use different colored frosting. Have fun!

After I uploaded this I just noticed SeiferTV must have made a similar design using the same template we found online! http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1179334
Use whichever one you want.

ATTENTION!: If toy damaged it can harm the health due to detached small parts of plastic.

Recomendation:
1- Select wheel with a suitable bearing gap (0.05mm, 0.1mm, 0.15mm) for you, and print it 4 times.
2- After printing Wheel-Bering Insert allen key into the cylinder hole and twist it. Do it for all cylinders in wheel.
3- Glue the wheels to car body and inserts.

remixed_from.title: Eachine QX90 tilted camera support - Front mounted (10°, 20°)

title: QX90 FPV Camera Mount and Top Plate

description.text:
So I basically wanted a modified camera mount, then a modified top plate and then I wanted something to hold the motors at the top as well as the bottom.
I then combined the XF90 frame and the top plate claw into a single piece for the top plate which now holds stop 8.5mm motors.
I also extended the camera mount so there's more material to hold onto the camera body.

I don't use anything to hold the camera in, just the printed parts as it's tight enough.
The top plate is screwed in using the front most holes and the slightly wider centre holes and the standoffs under both.
Using my settings I didn't need to make any modification to get the top plate over the motors and they fit snug but still move up and down if required just to take some strain off.

Thanks to the guys who made the original parts which allowed me to make this entire thing.
*Note: The top plate is in 2 version, the normal one is the full size motor holes which require you to use some spare rubber grommets like you use on the normal frame and the v1.1 is the smaller holes so the grommets aren't required.

remixed_from.author: enif
remixed_from.title: Flexing battery holders with integrated spring

title: 18650 snap-together tower of power (2,4,5,6 cell options)

description.text:
Stackable, snapable 18650 battery case. Super easy DIY variable-voltage 18650 battery packs without pesky cell soldering, and allowing for simple cell replacement. (useful if using reclaimed 18650 cells from...say...laptop battery packs)

Now includes 2, 5, and 6 cell versions. Haven't tried printing those, but should work just as well.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

30

Notes:

Used a 0.3 layer height for increased print speed.

UPDATE:
tinkercad link: https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4mitzZL41nM-18650x4-snap-case-12ga-wire-v81

v8.1 (see the pix of the grey case)
increased hole size to accommodate 12ga wire
moved wire holes up by 2mm so wire would contact battery ends closer to on-center
put cut-outs beneath batteries to make it easier to pop the buggers out
added negative wire blocks...made out of a cut medicine bottle. :-) (for a 3d printed one, see the remix)

see the most-excellent remix @ http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2280467 for a top-snapable lid!

Problem:

I wanted to build a high-voltage battery pack from laptop-reclaimed 18650 cells. DIY solutions either required:
soldering to the cells (heat can be bad for the cells, no good way to swap out bad cells)
spot welding (spot welders for this application are $$, also no way to swap out cells that go bad)
building (somewhat) elaborate enclosures that allowed for battery replacement. (I didn't have all the machining tools necessary)

All these solutions also required sanding/grinding off all the nasty little bits of nickel strip that remained after separating the batteries from their laptop bodies.

Solution:

Inspired by and building on enif's excellent 18650 battery case with built-in-spring ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:456900 ) , I did some tweaking. My solution allows for individual cell replacement while avoiding both heating the cell and the need to grind off the little residual bumpies! As a bonus, it’s extendable (adding/reducing voltage is trivial) and reasonably cheap. (assuming you can source a 3d printer)

Given the number of hours I spent revising, I wouldn’t say it qualified as a non-elaborate solution. For you however ... some 12ga stranded wire, 8mm m3 grub screws and (optionally) 10mm pan head m3 screws and you too can have a tower of power.

Model is for a 4 cell stack. However, it’d be easy enough to slice up the STL and splice in more cell slots in Tinkercad (which is what I used to begin with)

Details:
I printed mine @ 0.3mm resolution using PLA. Depending on your printer’s calibration (and mine...) you may need to scale the STL up or down 1-2%

The interconnect wire is 12ga stranded. It’s insulation is sliced (carefully) to expose 1/2 of the wire, for the length of the battery case. (picture is worth 1000 words) Battery modules have holes @ each end for the 12ga wire. Stranded gives the best connection if you’re lazy as I am and don’t bother to smooth the battery ends.

m3 grub screws hold the batteries tight and squish the wire against the battery terminals.
The current model’s wire holes are too small for 12ga wire. I drilled them out to fit.

Battery modules stack front-to-back to allow wire to loop from the + end of one set to the - of another. If they don’t snap together firmly enough for you, there are aligned holes for m3 pan-head screws to snug things together. This isn’t the optimum power-to-volume ratio, but it’ll work well enough for me to have the stack secreted away in paniers or in a bag mounted to a rear rack.

I haven’t actually used them in their intended application, as I realized that:
I wanted 10ah minimum of range
My recycled laptop cells averaged around 2000mah
My recycled laptop cells generally aren’t rated for the load an ebike will put on them.
I was out of season to ride the ebike, as fall had set in and I was driving kiddos to school every morning.

As a solution I’m thinking to build another stack to attach in parallel to the first. This should both double my range, and halve the amp draw on each set.

Future improvements:
Jig to make cutting the insulation off the wire easier
Some sort of flap to spread the load from the single grub screw point across the entire wire. Come to think of it, that’d also eliminate the need for fiddly wire 1/2 insulation stripping
Snap on fan mounts to allow adding cooling fans. (hot days, sudden acceleration are both good reasons for this)

OR...make said improvements yourself!

UPDATED LINK for v8.1
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/4mitzZL41nM-18650x4-snap-case-12ga-wire-v81

comments.text:
Shortly after I wrote you I completely stripped the wires and started putting a plastic disc in between the wire and the set screw as an insulator. I modified your design slightly as well. I have been using the design with minimal problems now for close to 3 weeks. Making good connections without spot welding is what held me back previously on these projects. The box that you remixed had a death grip on the batteries and I couldn't ever take them out. Connecting with thick wire and tensioning with set screws solves the problem. Kudos. This may not hold up over time on a bicycle as I have already had to tighten up the screws. Thanks again for your work.

description.text:
A slightly overkill replacement universal joint for the wand joint on window blinds. The hole at the top of the joint is 6.25 mm in diameter. This either friction fits over your existing shaft or you can glue it on. The gap in the bottom part of the joint where your wand slides into is 4.6 mm wide. Secure the top and bottom parts of the joint with wire.

description.header: Soon to be redesigned for PEEK application
description.text:
This setup is currently printing at 20 micron layers ;p This is a re-designed nozzle assembly for Ultimaker. No additional materials were required to fill gaps like PTFE tape or extruding ABS to fill gaps- as is the way for Ultimaker setup. Simply turn-up the white PTFE part tap some threads and screw together/ assemble. http://youtu.be/BVuYapH128k
http://youtu.be/CPiMJzieI6A
http://youtu.be/R-JmgTR4oQ4
PEEK PDF drawings now available. NOTE# Only use Makergear 36mm heater barrels and nozzles. The UM versions don't work with this design! There are 3mm and 1.75mm (BETA) versions of this design.

description.header: Note: if you unscrew and remove the Bowden tube for matinence. When reassembling unscrew the four long M3 screws and lower the entire print head assembly then insert the Bowden tube through the top hole and screw it back into the PTFE part and refit the print head. This avoids over tightening the Bowden tube into the PTFE part to much!
description.text:
You can purchase PEEK for RS in Australia. The M6x36mm brass tube and 0.35mm nozzle are from www.makergear.com and do not require PTFE tape to seal there presision machined and bed properly -
http://www.makergear.com/products/plastruder-replacement-parts
http://www.makergear.com/products/nozzles The following flickr image http://www.flickr.com/photos/scottmayson/6858896762/ has notes for the relavent dimensions. Central filament hole is 1/8" I will post a drawing soon if you want a shop to do it for you. In the meantime I had a play with tinkercad the students in our rapid class were talking about it. It's not bad Solidworks is my platform but they should be worried. https://tinkercad.com/things/iLvjDceNMLc I'll supply a solidworks part soon! dont fully trust the tinkercad part please ;p However, this part was machined to fit the existing Ultimaker bowden tube with M6 x 10mm thread cut by hand, alloy plate with four holes that fixes the nozzle in place and Makergear brass tube and nozzle. "Variation" The Bowden tube could have an M7 thread if cut by hand and matching M7 thread in PTFE component, The top will need to be shorter and rounder to allow for the M7 thread. Heater block recycled from Ultimaker. Tools required:
M6 tap intermediate and end
M6 Die
Lathe See the following videos of it in action.
http://youtu.be/BVuYapH128k
http://youtu.be/CPiMJzieI6A
http://youtu.be/R-JmgTR4oQ4

comments.text: Hey Scott... I made a handful of these, in ptfe and peek. I am curious what temps you are running them at? At 245 the peek expanded and contricted the 1/8" hole and locked up the filament (ABS) You can see the two white ones in the attached pic with intact filament stuck in them. I made a peek one the next day and any escaping molten filament solidifies as soon as it touches it. I do love the makergear nozzle and tube though, less damage to the bed if you you have a z collision and the longer tube it nice. I ended up using the makergear nozzle with the old peek. The longer tube gives you some options. I am going to try this design again with longer brass tube next and keep you posted.

comments.text: Hi Chuck, I print ABS at 242 deg, I have not had any back pressure with 36mm heater tube. I had a PTFE version and printed various companies PLA and ABS with it. Dont know what is going wrong for you. I use a 0.6mm nozzle maybe this makes a difference with back pressure? it can print to 20 microns. I have a new version as above and am trying (soon) 1.75mm filament. Its much nicer as theres half the mass to heat up etc.
comments.author: chasmaker

comments.text: that might be it... I am running the .35 mm nozzle. Did you see that ultimaker guys have a new nozzle coming out next week? the design doesn't seem that much different. The issue for me has always been back pressure liquid plastc making it's way back up the tube. Their new design doesn't seem to lengthen the tube at all.
comments.author: scottmayson

comments.text: Taylor and I were working on the same idea, using a M7 in the top part, and M6 for the brass tube, threading the bowden with M7 (easy by hand with a hex die). My part from PTFE was printing great at 250C (ABS, probably 235C real temp), but failed immediately at 255C, which seems to be the max temp for PTFE. If you are printing only PLA, this is a great solution, but the higher temp required for ABS pushes the PTFE beyond it's operational margin.

title: Prusa I3 MK2 Frame Holder Collection: 1 Filament Guide

description.text:
This is the first part of a little collection of frame holders for the Prusa I3 MK2 (should fit on the I3 MK1 as well). The collection will at least have the following useful holders:

  1. Filament guide (this part)
  2. LED light holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2055511)
  3. Spool holder (short and long) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2067538
  4. Camera mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2067731)
  5. Filament sensor holder for use with OctoPi

Each of these parts has been designed by different people already and there are many versions available. The idea behind the current collection is to use existing parts where possible and design parts that follow the same design principles (same or similar angles, lengths, same way of mounting to the frame etc.). This gives a much nicer, more homogenous look of the printer.

The first part is based on thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1657908 by Shii. I have adapted the upper part of the part to get similar as compared to the other parts of the collection. For frame bracket, I have used the original design from the Prusa spool holder. This will be used in all of the parts.

In addition, there is a little hole on the back of the bracket for cable management of the optional LED lights or the filament sensor.

The next parts of the collection will follow in the next couple of days.

title: University of Michigan Block M Magnet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a 3D printed Michigan Block M Magnet, based off my previous Michigan Block M, Thing:1103210. Use it to stick your degree on your fridge, or hang your student loan bills on the side of your stove, or just show your pride in being a Michigan Wolverine! Go Blue!

Printed using colors from this PLA multi color sample pack.
Magnets are installed with hot glue. Holes fit these magnets.

Be sure to check out my other Detroit and Michigan themed magnets!

  • Detroit Tigers Old English D
  • Detroit Lions
  • Detroit Red Wings Logo
  • Great Lakes State of Michigan - HOMES
  • Michigan State University Spartan
  • Smiley Face Magnets

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20-30%

Notes:

This design has spaces for two magnets. Magnets that will fit (and that I've used for many projects) can be found here on Amazon. They are plenty strong and come at a good price.

The maize and blue PLA I bought from Argos on Amazon. 3mm Maize PLA is here and 3mm Blue PLA is here. I cannot speak highly enough about this stuff, it is a good price, great tolerances (+- 0.01mm) and is made in USA. Check out these filaments if you need 1.75mm filament instead.

If you wish to print in maize and blue but only have a single extruder nozzle, you will need to separate your G-code files into multiple individual files. There are many instructions on how to do this online. Basically you can search through your G-code file by control finding the z heights of interest (eg. ctrl-f z5.4) and make each code file have only the z heights needed for each color step, you should also keep the relevant start and end code that sets temperatures, regimes axes, etc.

Here are the layer heights that I separated my file by when printing.

0.2 - 5.2 blue - insert magnets
5.4 - 6.2 blue
6.4 - 7.0 yellow
7.2 - 7.6 blue
7.8 - 8.4 yellow
8.6 - 9.0 blue
Depending on your printing dimensional tolerances, you may need to add some glue to make them stick. I like JB Weld but I'm sure other glues can work as well.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
This K-Cup holder is designed to hold both the reusable/refillable K-Cup as well as single-use pods. The holder has an angle on it to provide clearance for the cycling of the mechanism. This design works on my Keurig Model K50. It should work fine on similar models. The functionality mostly has to do with placement. I intend on modifying this design to accommodate models that are shaped differently. Also, feel free to remix this design to mount on different surfaces.

The mounting process is simple. I used indoor mounting tape (as shown in the picture having the green diamond pattern). Any double sided tape should work as long as it has good adhesion. Make sure you can open and close your machine without interference.

Below are two links to the products that I used.

Link to the refillable pod:
https://www.amazon.com/Keurig-5048-Reusable-Coffee-Filter/dp/B000DLB2FI/ref=sr_1_1?s=kitchen&ie=UTF8&qid=1485025767&sr=1-1&keywords=keurig+my+k+cup

Link to mounting tape:
https://www.amazon.com/Scotch-Indoor-Mounting-Tape-Heavy/dp/B00004Z4A8/ref=sr_1_13?ie=UTF8&qid=1485025971&sr=8-13&keywords=mounting+tape

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed this without any rafts or supports and it came out fine.
Material: PLA
Extruder Temp: 210 C
Heated Bed Temp: 55 C
I use a glass bed lightly sprayed with Aqua-Net to set a nice initial layer.
I measured my refillable pod to get the dimensions for the holder and used Autodesk 123D Design to draw the file.

The fan has captive m4 nut slots, but if you use it that way, it sucks air instead of pushing into the case. I flipped it around and used length crit screws.

Have an old Kenwood KM201 Chef Mixer and found an even older Blender for it. The problem was that the blender was designed for an longer axle thus the blender and axle never met each other even though the fastening was the same.
Drew a longer axle adapter for it, and was amazed that it fit and clicked in place straight away. Now the old blender spins happily in the somewhat less old KM201.

Probability states that no-one will ever need this part, but as you never know, i'll post it here for that unlikely event that someone would find use for it.

In short, print, then drill the holes to make a good pilot hole for the screws.
Cut off the end of a 9 volt plug-in adapter and secure the stripped leads to the holes before putting the screws back in. It's best if you run the screws in and out a few times so that you don't cut the wires with the screw threads. Make sure you get your polarity correct. the + is the smaller male connector on the battery and the - is the female snap.
In most instances you may have to cut an exit path for the cable through the battery door.
If you need extra space for the cable on the bottom of the "battery" then shrink (92-95%) your z axis to make the block shorter. Remember you need the width of the squashed wire plus the block height to keep the screws pressed against the contacts of your device.
If you printed it too short, maybe you can just not screw the screws in so far to compensate.

Print .2 - .3 with 4 shells (this provides enough support for the screws
Maybe 8-20% infill
I had a bit of issues with the print start at the bottom but it's hidden inside a battery door so I didn't stop the print so I apologize for the crappy print pic.

After I finished building my Kossel there were always issues to keep the hotend temperature stable. I noticed that with the original fan shroud the cold air was blown not only onto he cold zone but also to the hot end. The current design eliminates this issue and simply works. Also a small amount of the air is blown below the nozzle and improves bridging quality. I did want to keep the effector assembly as light as possible so another cooling fan was not an option. Also I removed the kapton and secured the thermistor with a bend piece of steel wire. It is fixed with a short M2.5 screw thats bolted into the thread of the fixations screw of the heater cartridge. Check the picture for details.
Align the fan-side to the print bed so you nearly need no support material. I printed it in PLA but ABS is fore sure the better choice.

Disclaimer:
Due to the recent incidents (things appearing on ebay) I just want to make something very clear:
I do not allow any commercial use of my STL-files, my designs and my photos! Description:
Maybe some of you remember my compressor wheel?
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53455
Nice to print but pretty much useless without a casing. So... I made a casing.
All you need is a motor and a battery. The backplate is designed to match a motor from an 1:18 RC model car (LRP Fusion Micro Modified 370). Hook it up to a battery and enjoy fresh, compressed air.
The compressor wheel has to spin clockwise.
Here is a video showing the compressor at work:
http://youtu.be/LF_rRPDeT54
EDIT:
I uploaded some models that are laying flat.

Print all three parts. You might want to use support for the compressor.
Bolt the motor to the blackplate and press-on the compressor wheel to the motor shaft.
Bolt the backplate to the compressor. The holes are designed for M2x8 bolts.

This is a model of car holder for a Nexus 5. It is designed to attach to a mount sold by Samsung meant for the Infuse. I simply removed the clip for the old phone and attached the new one. I used VHB tape. There is enough surface area that it should be able attach it to most mounts out there. This is similar to a project by Scroll http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:200073
That project was for a phone in a case and is meant to attach directly to the dashboard. This project assumes no case and some sort of mount. I have included STL and SW 2010 files for the holder and a rough version of the Nexus 5. DO NOT trust the Nexus 5 model. I was in a hurry and All I cared about was the bounds. I printed mine on a Replicator .2mm 10%

description.text:
!Disclosure! I list measurements from my personal machine, BUT, a large but, your machine may differ than mine. Before chopping up your probably not cheap acrylic sheets, please do your own measuring and use mine as a reference.

Okay I will try to describe this the best I can. First this enclosure is for The FolgerTech FT-5 and using a bowden setup with a e3d titan extruder. This may work with the stock extruder but not certain. Test it out and see :)

First I will go over the Bill of Materials.

BOM List:

x1-Extruder Mount
x3-Universal Hinges -----> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1209695
x1-Latch Assembly ------> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1844744
x6-T Brace
x1-Left T Brace with Front Brace
x1-Right T Brace with Front Brace
x1-Left Corner Brace with Front Brace
x1-Right Corner Brace with Front Brace
x7-Right Corner Brace
x6-Left Corner Brace
x1-TFT32 Mount Rev 2 (If no TFT32, Then replace this part with x1 Left Corner Brace)
x2-24in x 48in x 1/8in thick Sheet of Acrylic, PolyCarbonate, or Lexan
x1-Extra T Nuts (need a lot) --------> https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B019ZXUSY0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1
x1-Extra Screws (Also need a lot) --------> https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01G9HUYJO/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
x2-64 Screw Caps
x2-Filament holders -------> http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1813903
x1-16mm tube of >500mm for Spool holder

To assemble this together first printout/purchase all of the parts pertaining to this build. It will also be extremely wise to purchase or use a jigsaw to cut the acrylic. Use metal blades. This is the unit I used but of course buy or use what you would like ------> http://www.homedepot.com/p/Ryobi-6-1-Amp-Variable-Speed-Orbital-Jigsaw-with-Speed-Match-JS651L1/203146378

First is to cut the acrylic to size. There is a specifc way to cut the parts and I cannot model them up currently so I will try to describe it the best I can for now.

To start the measurements given can be off by roughly 1/16in - 1/8in maximum otherwise it will look like poo and not line up correctly. Use as many of the precut straight edges of the acrylic as you can. And only measure from precut edges. The goal is to figure out how to fit all the parts on the two sheets of acrylic you purchased. I did but I do not recall how I did. A quick sketch in CAD should do the trick for most.

First the front of the machine is all a single piece. So cut out that shape. Should be about 28 1/4in x 21 1/4in.

The Top is also a single piece. Size is 21 1/4in x 19 3/4in

The sides and rear I divided into two pieces; the lower section and the upper section. These sections I designate are divided by the 2020 that mounts the linear rails for the y axis. So cut a piece to fit into each section while still covering have of the middle 2020 piece ( added photos to help with this) Do this for the sides and rear. The rear you need to stop short of the power supply and mks board bay.

Sizes as follows:

Sides:
-Lower: 19 5/8in x 20 7/8in.
-Upper: 19 5/8in x 7 3/8in

Rear:
-Lower: 21 /14in x 13 3/8in
-Upper: 21 1/4in x 7 3/8in

The Last piece will be the door. I have my door at 13in x 20in and centered on the front piece. DO NOT TRY TO ENLARGE ABOVE 13in WIDE, IT WILL NOT WORK. Really I do not advise enlarging it at all from my measurements. It is a perfect size and you do not have much room to enlarge it (height wise).

Before final assembly two more things I will mention. First MAKE SURE YOUR PRINTER IS COMPLETELY SQUARED UP. Double check every measurement. I found my right y-axis linear rail was 1/8 inch lower than the left one. As well, remove the front middle 2020 section and cut it up. Note please make your own measurements for these as these can vary for each printer. My measurements are just for reference.

x2-2 7/8in sections
x2-6 1/4in sections

Hopefully you can figure out where these fit into ;)

Finally the assembly is fairly self explanatory. Lay the printer on its side so that the side you are working on it face-up. Makes a much easier platform to work on as it will not slide off or anything.

Align each section in their designated area. Place the coordinating braces in their positions so that the holes are centered over the groove of the 2020. Mark each hole with a sharpy and drill them out. Match the drill bit size with the hole size in the braces. Do this step for all the braces. I recommend lightly mounting on corner and then finish the section. Makes it much easier to drill the rest without the acrylic sliding around. (Note: when drilling rule of thumb. Make sure you drill all the way through, and quickly. When you pierce the arcylic and the drill bit puts a mark on the 2020 it is very convenient to use those marks later to put the t-nuts in) The additional screws that will use the screw caps (yellow squares in my pictures) you can just guesstimate or measure where these go. Feel what you think looks right. This is just to make sure the acrylic is completely fastened onto the frame.

When you get to marking up the top section, dont forget to drill out the slot for the motor wire to run though the acrylic. The Extruder mount uses that small slot in the stepper motor bay. As well don't forget to cut around the Spool mount holders which will need clearance since the mount on the inside of the FT-5 Frame (as pictured as well)

Okay so you now have all the mounting holes drilled out. Next will be to cut out a clearance guide slot for the bowden tube. Take one of the upper side sections, and drill two holes spaced out to whatever you find will work. I think mine are 14 inches apart with a 1/2 bit. After those holes are drilled, use the jigsaw and cut from one hole to the other creating a slot like pictured.

Another two holes to cut out are for the power plug as well as the usb for the mks board. Create slots the best of your ability.

The final cutting that will be needed is the door section cut out of the front section. Center up the shape of the door to the best you can (I would measure it all out and outline it with sharpy on the acrylic first.) And cut that out.

You should have no problems getting the rest of the enclosure sorted out (Door hinges and latch) mounted if you have made it this far.

Any questions please ask me on here or in the FolgerTech Forum/ Facebook Group.

Cheers!

description.text:
Not sure where I got the hinge and latch from but I'll try and give credit soon.

This is a single print. 0.2 resolution. Add support

Hinges were from:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:82533
I modeled this to hang my kids kindles on the wall while they charge.

So about a week ago, I had a brilliant idea, why not make a 3d printable thing that looks like it was braided together. Well, now I know why no one else has really done it. It requires an excessive amount of trial and error, and math.
(can't wait to see how I can port this into openscad...)

So yeah, about a week later, and a lot of time I should have spent studying/on homework later, I finally got this to where I am happy with it. The STL files are for a size 7 ring, and the Inventor ipt files include all the garbage for how it works, and stuff. I'll explain the how I designed this later. Hope you like it.

Final StepsSteps:

Make a 3D line that follows the equation below.
Draw ellipse on a plane perpendicular to that line.
Sweep ellipse along this line.
Circular pattern 2 more of them within 40 degrees.
That's it.

Logic Behind the formula: Just deciding on the type

So I guess I probably post my rough drafts of how I decided to braid stuff. It was a lot of try it and see, but in a nutshell, it was just a triangle that flipped 180 each 'step' of circles rotating clockwise which circle they went through. So my 6 planes ended up looking like this:
◀ ▶◀ ▶◀ ▶ I needed 6, since the period of rotation was top middle, bottom, bottom, middle, top. (see, with 3 strands, they need to wait 2 periods before they cross back through the middle.)
I decided circles were too wide and not tall enough so I quickly scratched that to ellipses.
I know that trig functions oscillate which is useful for 'bouncing' values back and forth.
I needed to bounce height and distance from center, so that's how I decided on using a cylindrical function.

So the equation that does it all. Logic Behind the formula: Where the values came from

r(t) =ringRadi+ellipseWidth+ellipseWidth(sin(periods2t))
θ(t) =t
z(t) =ellipseHeightfudgeFactorcos(periods/2*t)^2
Domain: 0:360
So that's what those values mean. The half and double are just cause how trig work. See, you want z(t) aka height to oscillate 6 whole periods. Or at least that's what I wanted when I made this one. So, to keep the min height equal to zero and also fudge the local maxima to have a lesser slope, I chose to square a cos function with half the desired period. Since the number of periods it would have then doubles.
using ellipseWidth for the xy plane makes sense, since that where you tell the thickness of the ring.
using ellipseHeight for the z makes sense cause well, that's the height and it needs to adjust accordingly.

description.text:
I created this power supply cover for my HICTOP 3DP-11 to provide a way to install a standard 3 Pin IEC320 C14 power socket with a power switch. Some other designs only cover the bottom portion of the power supply, but I wanted to test the limits of the large bed on my printer, so I decided to create a full cover. I also included cutouts at the bottom that will accommodate 1/2 inch split loom for the power supply and Z-axis motor cables.

Here is a link to the specific power socket I used, but there are several others in the same form factor you can choose from: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01LYMNQ2L

I recommend that the part be printed in ABS due to it's ability to withstand higher temperatures. The walls are 2mm thick, so I printed it at 250 microns with 1 mm perimeters, which made it solid.

V2 Update: Upper screw holes were in the incorrect location and added additional cooling slots.

Printer:

HICTOP 3DP-11

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

250 microns

Infill:

Full

Notes:

Set perimeters to 1 mm to achieve full infill. Since i printed it with ABS, I expanded the first layer by 20 loops to ensure that the corners would stay adhered to the bed during printing. I have PEI over glass on top of my aluminum print bed, so the expanded perimeter and setting the bed temperature to 110C worked great for keeping it stuck down.

Designed in OnShape

description.text:
This is my concept of a TOS styled Miranda. I designed it based on various people's ideas for what one would look like and cherry picked what I did and didn't like about other people's designs. I'm not sure there is a canonical version.

I did notice it was similar to Star Trek: New Voyages' Copernicus ship, which is pretty awesome. Those guys do great work. I almost regret not doing a straight model of their ship since it's such a nice design. However, I kind of like the more traditional engineering hull in my design.

Will fit a yoyo up to 65mm diameter with a 60mm width.

-temp: 190*
-First layer resolution: 0.35
-layer resolution: 0.25
-Raft: I didn't need one, but if your prints don't commonly stick well to your build platform then I would suggest one.

Remove Support

Here's what I did:
I used a sharp thin knife to separate the support from under the hole for the dremel and then used my dremel to smooth out the surface and edges. You could also use sand paper but dremel is easier.

Design Process

I just used a caliper to measure the girth of the dremel handle and recreated it used 123D design.

description.text:
This is a Customizable Vive Rifle made using 2 types of screws+nuts, 1/2" PVC Pipe, and 3D printed components.

I have designed this setup to be lightweight, easy to print and assembly, and most importantly, easy to use while in VR. The rear controller is fixed in place when using this setup and the front controller is removable using a quick connect attachment fixtured through the "donut" of the controller. Included are the files for an optional Shoulder strap.

  • This setup will work with both a rifle and a pistol in games such as Onward and H3VR.

I have tested this in H3VR and found that the only guns which do not work well are the ones where the magazine is behind the grip, since that space is taken by PVC in this design. I have not found a single rifle or pistol in Onward which did not function perfectly

To use it as a pistol you can use the optional shorter barrel, or simply use it as is. If you need to two hand a pistol (for example onward) you can attach the second controller as normal, then slide it back until it contacts the front of the rear controller, this is within the trigger distance for getting two handed mode in Onward. If you wanted you could then slide it forward and use your pistol like a rifle (it feels strange like this but it is effective).

I have a basic use tutorial on youtube at this link https://youtu.be/pqI15tz9wZA

Assembly instructions are detailed out below.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1-0.3 mm, It really shouldn't affect anything

Infill:

10-30% should be adequate

Notes:

Support:

Needed inside the "Bottom Cup,"

  • I have found that really just the center needs support (where there is a groove for a wrist strap), if you fill it with too much support it will become difficult to get out.

For the other components I used support inside the screw holes, and under significant overhangs, this will vary based on your own printers as to what is necessary.

Material:

  • I recommend PLA for the quick connect feature, this is the one feature that really relies on the material properties to get the "feel" right.
  • I recommend a softer material than PLA (ABS or EDGE) for the "Bottom Cup" feature. This is simply because PLA can be slightlly scratchy on the surface of the controller, so if that is something you care about keep this in mind.

EVERYDAY ASSEMBLY:

I am putting this at the top for convenience.

YOU DO NOT NEED A SCREWDRIVER FOR INSTALLATION OF THE CONTROLLERS.

Since both controllers are held in place with a Hex head fixed inside of a printed part it can be easily installed and removed.

To remove the rear controller you just need to use the controller screw (the one inset within the Printed part). If you unscrew this the controller can be pushed out.

This screw can be tightened quite tight, I have not had any fear of breaking the controller as of yet.

PRINTING:

I highly recommend using the customizer version I have included to get the exact dimensions of your fasteners, it will be a more convenient experience. For some reason the Preview in customizer only shows the rear of faces, I do not know how to fix this however the parts will come out fine from the customizer.

  • The customizer will produce one of each component when run, they will be saved as individual .stl files

  • The .stl files included on this thing are for the default settings of the customized part. These are the dimensions I used for my Vifle.

When sizing the screws in customizer I recommend to measure the dimensions and add at least 0.5 mm on top of that. With my printer and my experience I have found that to be a suitable tolerance to get a nice fit with screws in my printed parts. This value may be different for each printer.

Please print the quantities as follows:

1x Top_Quick_Connector

2x Shoulder_Strap (Optional)

2x Center_Screw_Bottom

1x Top_PVC_Connector

1x Rifle_Stock

1x Bottom_Cup

HARDWARE:

You will need 2 types of fasteners for this and 1/2 inch pvc pipe. Lengths can vary for these screws but should be as follows:

6x Pan Head Screws (+2x total if using shoulder straps, can be used without screws)

  • recommended 1.25 in or 30 mm length, can be longer (you may scratch yourself on the protrusion)
    • I personally used M4 x 30 mm Screws

6x Hex Nuts (+2x total if using shoulder straps

  • to match pan head screws

2x Hex Head Screws

  • recommended at least 1" or 25 mm long, max 35 mm long
  • I personally used 1/4" - 20 x 1" hex head
    2x Hex Nuts
    • to match Hex Head Screws
PVC HARDWARE:

links added for clarity, I recommend actually purchasing these through a local hardware store for price and convenience:

5ft 1/2" Standard PVC Pipe

  • https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MNIXTY6/ref=ox_sc_act_title_1?ie=UTF8&psc=1&smid=ATVPDKIKX0DER
  • I have attached a photo showing all the components and their basic lengths .

2x 1/2 " 45° Elbows

  • https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MNIZ6IS/ref=ox_sc_act_title_1?ie=UTF8&psc=1&smid=ATVPDKIKX0DER

1x 1/2" Tee junction

  • https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B007Q2HE0E/ref=ox_sc_act_title_1?ie=UTF8&psc=1&smid=ATVPDKIKX0DER

Other Notes:

  • The part attached to the "Rifle Stock" can be adjusted based on your arm size
  • The "Barrel" of the rifle can be made longer or shorter depending on your needs.
  • An alternate length of the Barrel is included for "Pistol Mode" where the Barrel is shortened for convenience.
OTHER HARDWARE:

For the shoulder strap I use: https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01E13DFRG/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_ep_dp_Qy9LybD9EESWS
I found this strap to be the right combination of length, price, and comfort.

I will re-iterate, this is NOT necessary for the assembly, I have included it as people often want a way to drop the controller. I do not use this regularly as I find it to be cumbersome.

ASSEMBLY:

I found that press fitting the PVC was all that was needed for strength. It also makes it very convenient to swap out components if desired.

You will need to drill a through hole for each of the screws used on the PVC connectors. - The easiest way is to assembly the components and use a sharpie to mark each side of the hole you want, then drill each side through (DON'T drill through both sides unless you are using a drill press, they will not line up easily). Once each side has been drilled use the drill to go through both sides at once, so as to remove any burrs and misalignment.

Be sure to test assembly with the controllers installed before drilling all the holes. Some variation from the PVC lengths I listed may be needed depending on your exact setup.

Assemble according to the attached photos, it should be self explanatory where each piece goes based on my exploded view.

I recommend having the "Bottom_Cup" slightly more forward on its PVC pipe than expected. This will effectively apply a pre-load on the controller and reduce the amount of wiggle from the PVC.

title: Emperor's Royal Guard / Red Guard - Star Wars printable figure

description.text:
The Emperor's Royal Guard, also referred to as the Imperial Royal Guard or Imperial Guard, was an elite order of protectors assigned to Emperor Sheev Palpatine of the Galactic Empire. Armed with force pikes and fully clad in their anonymous helmets and crimson robes, the Royal Guards were a silent, imposing, and deadly force in the Emperor's service. In addition to strict requirements of height, strength, intelligence, and loyalty, only the most capable soldiers in the Imperial Military qualified for duty in the ranks of the Royal Guard.
